text: Hi everyone, welcome to AnimationHub. In
this video, we're going to take the
comic style ink material to the next
level by adding color and specular
highlights. Let's get to it. In the
comic style ink video, we added ink
lines and cross-hatching to our basic
outline material. Now, let's add some
color and a specular highlight. In the
graph, you may see a few clamp nodes uh
that have been added to keep the value
constrained. And that just helps reduce
artifacts that can occur when you're
overdriv some of these values. So to do
this, press and hold the four key on the
keyboard and press the left mouse
button. This will create a vector 4
node. Right click on the node to convert
to parameter and name it color.
Dragging from the out pin of the clamp
node, type blend darken and hit the
enter key. This creates the blend darken
node. Connect the RGB pin on the color
node to the base input pin on the blend
node. Save and check the results.
Next, I've already built the graph for
the specular highlight. So, let's take a
look. Something familiar with right away
is the vector source and dotproduct
setup. This feeds into the value pin on
a smooth step node.
And then next we have parameter called
specular radius. And this runs through a
divide node to calculate greater
accuracy and then into a one minus node
to invert those results. The graph then
feeds into the min pin of the smooth
step node.
The specular factor parameter connected
to the max pin calculates how large the
range will be. One is the default and
lower values will give gray or faded
looking results.
Coming out of the smooth step node, we
feed into a multiply node with a
parameter connected called specular
hardness. This will further eliminate
any anti-aliased edges, keeping the
specular highlight smooth.
Coming from the out pin on the multiply
node, we use a blend lighten node
connecting the blend darken node from
having added the color graph previously
into the base of the blend lighten node.
The outpin for the blend light node then
feeds into the color and emissive color
pins on the material. And that's it.
Thanks for watching.
